question: A.1 [1.0 point] Which statement properly describes a thermal neutron?

answers.answer: a. A neutron at an energy level greater than its surroundings.
answers.feedback: Incorrect.  REFERENCE:  Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1982, Section 2.5

answers.answer: b. A neutron born directly from fission.
answers.feedback: Incorrect.  REFERENCE:  Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1982, Section 2.5

answers.answer: c. A neutron in equilibrium with its surroundings.
answers.feedback: Correct. REFERENCE:  Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1982, Section 2.5

answers.answer: d. A neutron born due to decay of a fission product.
answers.feedback: Incorrect.  REFERENCE:  Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1982, Section 2.5

question: A.2 [1.0 point] Reactor power is increasing on a 35-second period.  Approximately how long will it take for power to double?

answers.feedback: Incorrect.  REFERENCE:  P = Poe^t/T, time = ln(2)*35 = ~24 seconds
Correct. REFERENCE:  P = Poe^t/T, time = ln(2)*35 = ~24 seconds
Incorrect.  REFERENCE:  P = Poe^t/T, time = ln(2)*35 = ~24 seconds
Incorrect.  REFERENCE:  P = Poe^t/T, time = ln(2)*35 = ~24 seconds

question: A.3 [1.0 point] You are the reactor operator performing two pulsing operations.  The first pulse has a reactivity worth of $1.20 which results in a peak power of 200 MW.  If the second pulse has a peak power of 5000 MW, the corresponding reactivity worth is: Given: βeff=0.0070
A.4 [1.0 point] Which ONE of the following combinations of characteristics makes a good reflector?   Scattering Cross Section  Absorption Cross Section

answers.feedback: Correct. REFERENCE:  Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1988
Incorrect. REFERENCE:  Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1988
Incorrect. REFERENCE:  Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1988
Incorrect. REFERENCE:  Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1988

question: A.5 [1.0 point] Which ONE of the following is the time period in which the MAXIMUM amount of Xe-135 will be present in the core?

answers.answer: a. 8 hours after a startup to 100% power
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REFERENCE:  Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1988, Section 8.4, page 8-9

answers.answer: b. 8 hours after a scram from 100% power
answers.feedback: Correct. REFERENCE:  Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1988, Section 8.4, page 8-9

answers.answer: c. 8 hours after a power increase from 50% to 100%
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REFERENCE:  Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1988, Section 8.4, page 8-9

answers.answer: d. 8 hours after a power decrease from 100% to 50%
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REFERENCE:  Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1988, Section 8.4, page 8-9

question: A.6 [1.0 point] Which ONE of the following is the stable reactor period which will result in a power rise from 25% to 100% power in 75 seconds?

answers.feedback: Incorrect. REFERENCE:  P = P0e^t/T, T = t / (ln(P/P0) = 75 / (ln(4)) = 54 seconds
Correct. REFERENCE:  P = P0e^t/T, T = t / (ln(P/P0) = 75 / (ln(4)) = 54 seconds
Incorrect. REFERENCE:  P = P0e^t/T, T = t / (ln(P/P0) = 75 / (ln(4)) = 54 seconds
Incorrect. REFERENCE:  P = P0e^t/T, T = t / (ln(P/P0) = 75 / (ln(4)) = 54 seconds

question: A.7 [1.0 point] During a reactor startup, as Keff approaches criticality, the value of 1/M:

answers.feedback: Correct. REFERENCE:  Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1988, Section 5.4, Fig. 5.2
Incorrect. REFERENCE:  Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1988, Section 5.4, Fig. 5.2
Incorrect. REFERENCE:  Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1988, Section 5.4, Fig. 5.2
Incorrect. REFERENCE:  Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1988, Section 5.4, Fig. 5.2

question: A.8 [1.0 point] In a subcritical reactor, Keff is increased from 0.918 to 0.965.  Which one of the following is the amount of reactivity that was added to the core?

answers.feedback: Incorrect. REFERENCE:  Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1988, Section 3.3.4 Δρ = (Keff1-Keff2)/(Keff1*Keff2) = (0.965-0.918)/((0.965*0.918) = 0.0531Δk/k = 5.31%Δk/k
Correct. REFERENCE:  Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1988, Section 3.3.4 Δρ = (Keff1-Keff2)/(Keff1*Keff2) = (0.965-0.918)/((0.965*0.918) = 0.0531Δk/k = 5.31%Δk/k
Incorrect. REFERENCE:  Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1988, Section 3.3.4 Δρ = (Keff1-Keff2)/(Keff1*Keff2) = (0.965-0.918)/((0.965*0.918) = 0.0531Δk/k = 5.31%Δk/k
Incorrect. REFERENCE:  Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1988, Section 3.3.4 Δρ = (Keff1-Keff2)/(Keff1*Keff2) = (0.965-0.918)/((0.965*0.918) = 0.0531Δk/k = 5.31%Δk/k

question: A.9 [1.0 point] Which ONE of the following statements best describes on how an INCREASE in moderator temperature affects the core operating characteristics?

answers.answer: a. Will DECREASE the neutron multiplication factor due to the resonance escape probability DECREASE
answers.feedback: Correct. REFERENCE:  Burn, R., Introduction of Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1988, Section 3.3.1

answers.answer: b. Will INCREASE the neutron multiplication factor due to the resonance escape probability INCREASE
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REFERENCE:  Burn, R., Introduction of Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1988, Section 3.3.1

answers.answer: c. Will INCREASE the neutron multiplication factor due to the reproduction factor DECREASE
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REFERENCE:  Burn, R., Introduction of Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1988, Section 3.3.1

answers.answer: d.  Will DECREASE the neutron multiplication factor due to the reproduction factor INCREASE
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REFERENCE:  Burn, R., Introduction of Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1988, Section 3.3.1

question: A.10 [1.0 point] Which ONE of the following best describes beta decay (β-1) of a nucleus?

answers.answer: a. Atomic mass number increases by 1, and the number of protons increases by 1
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REFERENCE:  Chart of Nuclides

answers.answer: b. Atomic mass number increases by 1, and the number of protons decreases by 1
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REFERENCE:  Chart of Nuclides

answers.answer: c. Atomic mass number remains unchanged, and the number of protons increases by 1
answers.feedback: Correct. REFERENCE:  Chart of Nuclides

answers.answer: d. Atomic mass number remains unchanged, and the number of protons decreases by 1
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REFERENCE:  Chart of Nuclides

question: A.11 [1.0 point] Assume that the worths of the Safety, Shim, and Reg rods are $4.50, $3.75, and $2.00, respectively.  The reactor is critical at 15 W after WITHDRAWING the following control rod worths: Safety $3.50, Shim $2.00, and Reg $1.50.  What is the CORE EXCESS?

answers.feedback: Incorrect. REFERENCE:  Total Worth = $4.50 + $3.75 + $2.00 = $10.25   Reactivity at 15W = $3.50 + $2.00 + $1.50 = $7.00   Core Excess = Total Worth – Reactivity at 15W = $10.25 - $7.00 = $3.25
Correct. REFERENCE:  Total Worth = $4.50 + $3.75 + $2.00 = $10.25   Reactivity at 15W = $3.50 + $2.00 + $1.50 = $7.00   Core Excess = Total Worth – Reactivity at 15W = $10.25 - $7.00 = $3.25
Incorrect. REFERENCE:  Total Worth = $4.50 + $3.75 + $2.00 = $10.25   Reactivity at 15W = $3.50 + $2.00 + $1.50 = $7.00   Core Excess = Total Worth – Reactivity at 15W = $10.25 - $7.00 = $3.25
Incorrect. REFERENCE:  Total Worth = $4.50 + $3.75 + $2.00 = $10.25   Reactivity at 15W = $3.50 + $2.00 + $1.50 = $7.00   Core Excess = Total Worth – Reactivity at 15W = $10.25 - $7.00 = $3.25

question: A.12 [1.0 point] Which ONE of the following parameters is MOST significant in determining the differential rod worth of a control rod?

answers.feedback: Incorrect. REFERENCE:  Burn, R., Introduction of Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1988, Section 7.2
Incorrect. REFERENCE:  Burn, R., Introduction of Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1988, Section 7.2
Incorrect. REFERENCE:  Burn, R., Introduction of Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1988, Section 7.2
Correct. REFERENCE:  Burn, R., Introduction of Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1988, Section 7.2

question: A.13 [1.0 point] What has the greatest affect on the THERMAL UTILIZATION FACTOR in the “six factor” formula?

answers.feedback: Incorrect. REFERENCE:  Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1988, Sec 3.3.2
Incorrect. REFERENCE:  Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1988, Sec 3.3.2
Correct. REFERENCE:  Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1988, Sec 3.3.2
Incorrect. REFERENCE:  Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1988, Sec 3.3.2

question: A.14 [1.0 point] The reactor is on a CONSTANT positive period.  Which ONE of the following power changes will take the LEAST time to complete?

answers.feedback: Incorrect. REFERENCE:  Assume constant period = 1, P = P0e^t/T, t = T*ln(P/P0), smallest ratio of P/P0 takes   the least time to complete
Incorrect. REFERENCE:  Assume constant period = 1, P = P0e^t/T, t = T*ln(P/P0), smallest ratio of P/P0 takes   the least time to complete
Correct. REFERENCE:  Assume constant period = 1, P = P0e^t/T, t = T*ln(P/P0), smallest ratio of P/P0 takes   the least time to complete
Incorrect. REFERENCE:  Assume constant period = 1, P = P0e^t/T, t = T*ln(P/P0), smallest ratio of P/P0 takes   the least time to complete

question: A.15 [1.0 point] In a just critical reactor, the MOST LIKELY result of ADDING $1.00 of reactivity will cause:

answers.answer: a. The resultant period to be a function of the prompt neutron lifetime
answers.feedback: Correct. REFERENCE:  Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1988, Section 4.2, page 4-4

answers.answer: b. The reactor period to be equal to (β – ρ)/(λ*ρ)
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REFERENCE:  Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1988, Section 4.2, page 4-4

answers.answer: c. A sudden increase in delayed neutrons
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REFERENCE:  Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1988, Section 4.2, page 4-4

answers.answer: d. A sudden drop in neutron flux
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REFERENCE:  Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1988, Section 4.2, page 4-4

question: A.16 [1.0 point] ELASTIC SCATTERING is the process by which a neutron collides with a ground state nucleus and:

answers.answer: a. is absorbed, with the nucleus emitting a gamma ray and a neutron with a lower kinetic energy
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REFERENCE:  Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1988, Section 2.4

answers.answer: b. recoils with a  higher kinetic energy than it had prior to the collision with the nucleus emitting a gamma ray
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REFERENCE:  Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1988, Section 2.4

answers.answer: c. is absorbed, with the nucleus emitting a gamma ray
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REFERENCE:  Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1988, Section 2.4

answers.answer: d. recoils with the same kinetic energy it had prior to the collision
answers.feedback: Correct. REFERENCE:  Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1988, Section 2.4

question: A.17 [1.0 point] Which ONE of the following is the MOST reason that causes the reactor power to rapidly decrease in the U-ZrH material used in the TRIGA fuel due to a rapid power excursion (rapid reactivity change)?

answers.answer: a. By increasing of the reproduction factor
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REFERENCE:  SAR Chapter 3

answers.answer: b. By decreasing of the reproduction factor
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REFERENCE:  SAR Chapter 3

answers.answer: c. By increasing of the thermal utilization factor
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REFERENCE:  SAR Chapter 3

answers.answer: d. By decreasing of the thermal utilization factor
answers.feedback: Correct. REFERENCE:  SAR Chapter 3

question: A.18 [1.0 point] A reactor with Keff = 0.7 contributes 1500 neutrons in the first generation.  Changing from the first generation to the third generation, the number of TOTAL neutrons in the THIRD generation is:

answers.feedback: Incorrect. REFERENCE:  Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1988, Section 5.3, page 5-5   2nd Gen = n + K*n = 1500 + (0.7 * 1500) = 2550   3rd Gen = n + K*n = 2550 + (0.7 * 2550) = 4335

Correct. REFERENCE:  Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1988, Section 5.3, page 5-5   2nd Gen = n + K*n = 1500 + (0.7 * 1500) = 2550   3rd Gen = n + K*n = 2550 + (0.7 * 2550) = 4335

Incorrect. REFERENCE:  Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1988, Section 5.3, page 5-5   2nd Gen = n + K*n = 1500 + (0.7 * 1500) = 2550   3rd Gen = n + K*n = 2550 + (0.7 * 2550) = 4335

Incorrect. REFERENCE:  Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1988, Section 5.3, page 5-5   2nd Gen = n + K*n = 1500 + (0.7 * 1500) = 2550   3rd Gen = n + K*n = 2550 + (0.7 * 2550) = 4335

question: A.19 [1.0 point] The scram setpoint of a reactor is 1100 kW and the computer system delay prior to initiation of the rod drop is 0.05 seconds.  If an injection of a sample results in a 100 millisecond period, which ONE of the following is the peak power of the reactor at SHUTDOWN?

answers.feedback: Incorrect. REFERENCE:  P = P0e^t/T = 1100kW * e(0.05/0.1) = 1813 kW
Incorrect. REFERENCE:  P = P0e^t/T = 1100kW * e(0.05/0.1) = 1813 kW
Correct. REFERENCE:  P = P0e^t/T = 1100kW * e(0.05/0.1) = 1813 kW
Incorrect. REFERENCE:  P = P0e^t/T = 1100kW * e(0.05/0.1) = 1813 kW

question: A.20 [1.0 point] Which ONE of the following describes how delayed neutrons are produced?

answers.feedback: Incorrect. REFERENCE:  Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1988, Sec 3.2.2
Correct. REFERENCE:  Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1988, Sec 3.2.2
Incorrect. REFERENCE:  Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1988, Sec 3.2.2
Incorrect. REFERENCE:  Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1988, Sec 3.2.2
